metadata.case_name: State of Uttar Pradesh v. Hafiz Mohammad Ismail and Hafiz Jawed Ali

facts.text: Bhagwan Swarup Saxena, Trade Marks Investigator of Lever Brothers Ltd., investigated manufacture and sale of counterfeit Sunlight and Lifebuoy soaps in Yahiaganj and other places in Lucknow.
Two soap factories in Lucknow were manufacturing counterfeit Sunlight and Lifebuoy soaps.
Hafiz Mohammad Ismail and Hafiz Jawed Ali (respondents) were selling counterfeit soaps in their shops in Yahiaganj.
Raid conducted on respondents' shops on May 19, 1953, with police help; large number of soaps recovered wrapped in labels said to be counterfeits of genuine Sunlight and Lifebuoy soaps.
Respondents prosecuted under ss. 482 and 486 of Indian Penal Code.
Magistrate found case proved, held labels counterfeit, convicted respondents under ss. 482 and 486 IPC.
Sessions Judge (Second Civil and Sessions Judge, Lucknow) dismissed respondents' appeals in Criminal Appeals Nos. 511 and 512 of 1954 on March 31, 1954.

Allahabad High Court (Lucknow Bench) in Criminal Revisions Nos. 118 and 119 of 1955, judgment dated July 13, 1956, held cases do not fall under s. 482 IPC, acquitted thereunder; held labels not counterfeit but colourable imitations, acquitted under s. 486 IPC without considering other points.
State of Uttar Pradesh's application for certificate to appeal rejected by High Court; special leave granted by Supreme Court.
Magistrate and Sessions Judge examined wrappers/labels, compared with genuine, found resemblance close enough to deceive.
Supreme Court examined labels/wrappers, agreed with Magistrate and Sessions Judge that resemblance such that person may be deceived.

legal_issues.text: Whether the labels/wrappers on soaps sold by respondents are 'counterfeit' trade marks within meaning of s. 28 and s. 486 IPC, or mere colourable imitations.
Application of Explanations 1 and 2 to s. 28 IPC to determine counterfeiting despite differences in detail.

petitioner_arguments.text: High Court erred in holding wrappers/labels only colourable imitations and not counterfeit; failed to apply s. 28 IPC and its Explanations fully.
Counterfeiting under s. 28 requires resemblance likely to deceive, not exact imitation; presumption under Expl. 2 if resemblance might deceive; no proof to rebut.

respondent_arguments.text: Labels/wrappers are colourable imitations, not counterfeit; differences in detail prevent deception.

court_reasoning.text: S. 28 defines counterfeit as causing one thing to resemble another intending/knowing deception likely; Expl. 1: imitation need not be exact; Expl. 2: presumption of intent/knowledge if resemblance might deceive, rebuttable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need for 'colourable imitation'; focus on resemblance likely to deceive.

court_reasoning.text: High Court acknowledged resemblance (called colourable imitations) but overlooked Expl. 1; failed to assess if resemblance might deceive despite differences noticed by lower courts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lower courts found resemblance deceptive; Supreme Court agrees upon examination.

court_reasoning.text: Expl. 2 applies; no contrary proved; thus intention/knowledge presumed; labels counterfeit.

holdings.text: Labels/wrappers counterfeit under s. 28 IPC as resemblance such that person might be deceived; presumption under Expl. 2 applies, not rebutted.
Acquittal under s. 482 stands as not pressed.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: S. 28 defines 'counterfeit'; s. 486 punishes selling goods with counterfeit trade mark; s. 482 not pressed.

outcome.summary: Appeals allowed on s. 486 IPC; acquittal set aside, respondents' labels held counterfeit, convictions restored subject to consideration of jurisdiction, limitation, and protections under cls. (a) and (b) not addressed by High Court.
outcome.relief_granted: Restoration of conviction under s. 486 IPC

key_quotes.text: "It is not essential to counterfeiting that the imitation should be exact."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Expl. 1 to s. 28 IPC; rejects High Court's emphasis on differences in detail.

key_quotes.text: "When a person causes one thing to resemble another thing, and the resemblance is such that a person might be deceived thereby, it shall be presumed..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Expl. 2 to s. 28; applies presumption of intent/knowledge.

key_quotes.text: "We have looked at the labels and wrappers... and we agree... that the resemblance is such that a person may be deceived by it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Supreme Court's independent finding affirming lower courts.
